emkornfield commented on pull request #4585: ARROW-5569: [C++] Avro import
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585
 
 
   This PR just copies code from avro C++ api/impl/test directories with the following modifications:
   1.  Puts all files in one directory
   2.  Renames all files to snake_case instead of CamelCase.
   3.  Run a make format.
   
   For now files are excluded from linting.
   
   Getting the code to actually build is covered by a separate JIRA and will have a separate PR.  I'm doing this first so subsequent PRs can show more accurately the actual diffs required.

emkornfield commented on issue #4585: ARROW-5569: [C++] Avro import
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585#issuecomment-502756449
 
 
   @pitrou the intent was to start from known working code and pair it down/ adapt it to our style standards.  Doing the initial import was meant to make reviewers life easier so it would be obvious what changes were being made from the original code.  At least some code also duplicates existing libraries and will be deleted as part of the adaptation.
   
   The fork in general is because we feel we will ultimately do more advanced things for avro like code generation that would be difficult to merge upstream (and  avoid slow upstream release cycles).
   
   If you prefer I can attempt to do the adaptation as part of this PR or if you have a different preferred strategy I would probably be OK with another approach
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #4585: ARROW-5569: [C++] Avro import
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585#issuecomment-502763091
 
 
   Forking sounds like a can of worms to me. How do ensure we remain compatible with upstream? How do we backport fixes and improvements?
   
   I'm also skeptical that this has to be in the Arrow main repo. It seems we're already exploding under the constraints of wrangling together multiple languages and components. Every release we have to firefight building and packaging issues that appear because of various changes (internal or external).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

emkornfield commented on issue #4585: ARROW-5569: [C++] Avro import
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585#issuecomment-502765375
 
 
   @pitrou We take ownership of compatibility upstream, luckily the Avro format has been around for a while and fairly stable.  I agree it is a risk. (Same applies to back-ports/fixes).
   
   I think having this in the Arrow repo reduces potential breakages (one less external dependencies), I believe this is why we have Parquet in the main repo also.

wesm commented on issue #4585: ARROW-5569: [C++] Avro import
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585#issuecomment-502768218
 
 
   The thesis would be that a high quality Arrow-friendly Avro implementation will attract users and developers into the project alike. The reason we are here discussing this at all is that Google relies on Avro for BigQuery platform support, so this is a possible hook to have Google invested in maintenance and support of this part of the project.
   
   Note that Avro support in general is a mess -- I'm aware of at least 4 Python libraries (avro, fastavro, uavro, cyavro) for us, all of which have different levels of features and serialization performance. I think that taking ownership of the code is the least-bad thing we can do given that the Apache Avro community has been stagnant in recent years, though it's improving lately. 
   
   Bottom line is that if the goal is to deliver first-rate Avro support to Arrow users I think this approach is the best option compared with doing work upstream in Apache Avro (where we lack committers and PMC members) and trying to get the Avro community to make releases that are compatible with our much-faster release timelines
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4585#issuecomment-502910789
 
 
   Another perspective: this codebase is almost 10 years old, and primarily has a single developer:
   
   ```
   $ git shortlog -sn lang/c++/
       60  Thiruvalluvan M. G
       36  Thiruvalluvan M G
       11  Scott Banachowski
        7  Ryan Blue
        6  Douglass Cutting
        5  Doug Cutting
        4  Victor Mota
        4  da77a
        3  Niels Basjes
        3  William Matthews
        2  Aniket Mokashi
        1  Daniel Kulp
        1  Eric Rosenquist
        1  JamesAdams800
        1  Karl Wallner
        1  Marcus Kempe
        1  Marius Van Niekerk
        1  Purushotham Nayak
        1  Romain Geissler
        1  Sandeep Joshi
        1  Thomas White
        1  Tom White
        1  Zoltan Farkas
        1  Zoltan Ivanfi
        1  jmccl
        1  skarlsson
   ```
   
   This does not look to me like software that is at risk of becoming burdensome due to upstream patches. 
   
   Not only that, but it may require significant changes in order to have better "Arrow affinity".

fields.description: The goal here is to take code as is without compiling it, but flattening it to conform with Arrow's code base standards.  This will give a basis for future PR.
fields.summary: [C++] import avro C++ code to code base.

comments.body: Is this still something we want to pursue?
I think so.  I probably won't get to this until sometime in 2021 though at the earliest, so we can possible close and I can reopen later.

Of note: if we want to support Apache Iceberg in Datasets, we may want an Avro to Arrow reader for the [manifest files|https://www.dremio.com/apache-iceberg-an-architectural-look-under-the-covers/#manifest-file], which I imagine could get big and numerous in large tables.
[~willjones127] agreed.  If you want to pursue support for iceberg, I'd approve and try to help out with reviews.  At the moment it isn't clear when I will get to this.

This issue was last updated over 90 days ago, which may be an indication it is no longer being actively worked. To better reflect the current state, the issue is being unassigned. Please feel free to re-take assignment of the issue if it is being actively worked, or if you plan to start that work soon.
